Detailed Description

Provides an object encapsulation for a Windows thread.

The thread class provides an easy way to create a class which has threaded functionality. The class provides simple encapsulation of the creation of a thread, with synchronisation on termination.

Member Function Documentation

static DWORD WINAPI Thread::kickstart (  LPVOID  pClass  )  [inline, static, private]
 

Static kickstart routine.

This is the starting point for the new windows thread. A thread must be created to start in a static, or non-class member, function. When creating a thread a context pointer may be specified which is passed to the new thread. The class instance pointer (this) is used in this case, which allows the kickstart function to call the main() member function.

Definition at line 106 of file thread.h.

int Thread::main (   )  [protected, virtual]
 

Main routine, should be overridden to use thread.

The main function forms the body of the thread. To synchronise with thre rest of the class the main function must carry out the following operations:

  • Signal the sychronisation event m_hSynchroEvent as soon as any initialisation has been carried out, this releases the run() function.
  • Cease operating as quickly as possible when the termination event m_hTerminateEvent is signalled.
  • Signal the sychronisation event m_hSynchroEvent as soon as any termination tasks have been carried out, this releases the terminate() function. This should be the last thing a thread does.

Reimplemented in Server.

Definition at line 133 of file thread.cpp.

int Thread::run (   ) 
 

Run this thread.

Creates a thread and sets it running. Does not return until the main() function signals it via the synchronisation event m_hSynchroEvent.

Definition at line 58 of file thread.cpp.

void Thread::terminate (   ) 
 

Terminate this thread.

Signals the thread main() routine to terminate via the termination event m_hTerminateEvent. Does not return until the main() function signals it via the synchronisation event m_hSynchroEvent.

Definition at line 104 of file thread.cpp.

Member Data Documentation

HANDLE Thread::m_hMutex [protected]
 

The thread handle protection mutex.

This mutex must be acquired in order to read or write the thread handle m_hThread. This ensures the value read is always correct.

Definition at line 79 of file thread.h.

HANDLE Thread::m_hSynchroEvent [protected]
 

The synchronisation event.

Used once to idicate that the thread has completed initialisation and is running properly, freeing the run() function. Used a second time, after the termination event m_hTerminateEvent is signalled, to indicate that the thread has completed, freeing the terminate() function.

Definition at line 88 of file thread.h.

HANDLE Thread::m_hTerminateEvent [protected]
 

The termination event.

This event is signalled to indicate that the thread main() function should cease operating as soon as possible.

Definition at line 94 of file thread.h.

HANDLE Thread::m_hThread [protected]
 

The thread handle.

The handle of the running thread, or NULL if the thread is not running.
